A few days ago and for a few hours last night, it looked as if a Donald Trump victory was perhaps the only thing standing in the way of a Federal Reserve rate hike in December.Some economists had even suggested Janet Yellen would have to resign if Trump won, after he attacked her for running a Fed that acted "more political than Secretary Clinton."Now, in the light of day, as markets process the likely direction of a Trump presidency, the Fed's green light is back.After tumbling overnight, the 10-year Treasury yield surged above 2%, hitting their highest levels since January. Stocks are rallying solidly in late-afternoon trading, easing concerns that markets won't be able to handle higher rates. The odds of a Fed hike next month, which briefly dipped below 50% overnight, are back to 71.5%.Plus, Trump will be able to nominate two members to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. He's warned that ultralow rates are fomenting bubbles, suggesting that he might pick more hawkish policymakers.Shares of U.S. Bancorp (USB), which saw its shares rise to a 52-week high on Tuesday when Hillary Clinton looked like a winner, surged 3.8% to an all-time high on Wednesday despite the altered political reality. Shares of Bank of America (BAC) advanced 5.7% to the top of a 12-month base.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) hit an all-time high, closing up 4.6%. PNC Financial Services (PNC) rose 4.8% to its own record high.IBD'S TAKE: Markets may stay volatile as investors figure out what a Donald Trump presidency means, but don't lose sight of the big picture. For a primer on how to know if the market is ripe for gains and it's a favorable time to establish new positions, visit IBD University. Then read The Big Picture each day to stay on top of the market's prevailing trend.Now, investors seems to believe, banks can enjoy not only the higher interest-rate environment that will help net-interest margins, but they'll also benefit from a lighter regulatory touch under Trump.What happened to change the mood so suddenly? Credit Trump's gracious speech early Wednesday morning, says Harm Bandholz, chief U.S. economist at UniCredit Research."Trump's speech helped to calm down markets" because it lacked the aggressiveness that defined his campaign, Bandholz said.Still, Bandholz notes, everything Trump says is now under the microscope. New talk of tariffs, the market's biggest fear, could upset the new equilibrium.During the campaign, Trump threatened to walk away from Nafta unless Mexico renegotiates the agreement under favorable terms for the U.S., and he pledged that his administration would slap the currency manipulator label on China, paving the way for punitive tariffs.Uncertainty about he'll make good on his campaign pledges will likely increase the volatility of the market, Bandholz says. But for now, wage growth has picked up, inflation is rising, albeit from a low base, and there's little chance the data will shift before the Fed makes its next interest-rate decision on December 14.As for Yellen, she has dismissed any charge that the Fed held off on raising rates this year to help Hillary Clinton."We do not discuss politics at our meetings, and we do not take politics into account in our decisions," Yellen said at a post-meeting press conference in September.If she believes in the importance of the Fed's independence, she's unlikely to take the fall because of some rough campaign words.The surge in Treasury yields on Wednesday comes after Trump signaled that his top priority is to get the economy humming — "we will double our growth" — via infrastructure spending and tax cuts.Fitch Ratings warned on Wednesday that Trump's agenda could be negative for U.S. creditworthiness since it could potentially put upward pressure on already-rising deficits and debt levels.Yet Bandholz sees little risk that Trump's big infrastructure splurge will lead the U.S. economy to overheat, forcing the Fed to move quickly. He notes that any package will either require Democratic support in the Senate or, if done through reconciliation to get around a filibuster, would have to be revenue neutral.RELATED:The Fed Isn't Ruled By Politics — But Here's Why It Soon Might BeAfter Initial Fall, Stocks May Rally On Trump Victory, Agenda

Super-regional banks are plenty big, but not too big to fail. The industry has been a relatively sweet spot for investors recently, and it may be sweeter still under President Donald Trump. Despite a slow-growth economic environment, the increasing likelihood of a resumption in Federal Reserve rate hikes, the prospect of some regulatory relief for banks — especially those that don't pose systemic…

U.S. Bancorp (USB) Chief Executive Richard Davis said during his company's third-quarter conference call that banks were still working to revive their reputations, after years of economic scandal, most recently involving Wells Fargo's (WFC) illicit opening of accounts. "People love their banker, they like their bank, because they made those choices," Davis said. "They don't so much like the industry.…

Riding a spike in Treasury yields, bank stocks like JPMorgan (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) rose to their highest levels in years, continuing their gains since Donald Trump's unexpected election last week.JPMorgan jumped 3.7% in the stock market today, after hitting a record high last week. Bank of America rose 5.6% to levels not seen since 2008. Citigroup (C) advanced 3.5%, while Wells Fargo (WFC) gained 2.2%.Goldman Sachs (GS) was up 2.6%, while Morgan Stanley (MS) added 2.2%. U.S. Bancorp (USB) rose 1.7%, KeyCorp (KEY) 2.8% and PNC Financial Services (PNC) 2%.Home Bancorp (HOMB), Western Alliance Bancorp (WAL) and East West Bancorp (EWBC) are among the many other banking stocks extending powerful gains.Those stocks are all well past buy range, but could still maintain strength and present buying opportunities in the event of a correction.The yield on 10-year Treasury notes leapt 10 basis points to 2.25%, continuing huge gains since last week. SPDR Financial (XLF) an ETF whose investments include a variety of financial stocks, rose 1.8%.IBD'S TAKE: Ever since President-elect Trump last vowed to improve the nation's infrastructure, investors have renewed their focus on the stocks that could benefit. Here's a broader look at what stocks could drive a potential bull market in the Trump era.The rising yields come as investors anticipate stronger growth and higher inflation due to Trump's plans for tax cuts a wave of new public infrastructure spending. Markets are also betting that the Federal Reserve will raise rates next month, with perhaps more tightening in 2017.Short-end Treasury yields also have risen sharply since the election and in recent weeks, but not nearly as much as the long end. That means banks, which borrow short and lend long, should see higher profitability.Banks could also benefit from fewer regulations under a Trump administration.RELATED:Profit Recession Over, Here Comes The Best Earnings Growth Since 2014Banks ETFs Rise To Build On Trump Windfall, At Best Level Since 2008JPMorgan Hits Record As Banks Extend Gains; CEO Dimon At Treasury?U.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials Teeter

Stocks opened higher Friday, buoyed by economic data and overseas trade, ahead of a session chock full of bank reports and Fed commentary.Dow industrials scaled up 0.8%. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq advanced 0.6%.Earnings reports rolled out from JPMorgan (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and PNC Financial (PNC) early Friday. Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren spoke at 8:30 a.m. ET. Loretta Mester, president of the Cleveland Federal Reserve, speaks at 12 p.m., just before Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen addresses the Boston Fed's economics conference.Europe's markets stuck with their early gains, rebounding from Thursday's difficult session with mining and telecom plays leading the gains. The CAC 40 in Paris was up 1.9% in afternoon trade, Frankfurt's DAX leapt 1.6% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.9% gain.Financials held the top of the Dow, with Goldman Sachs (GS) up 2.6% and JPMorgan notching a 1.2% gain. JPMorgan reported broad third-quarter beats on both its revenue and earnings lines, boosted by record results at its investment bank.Citigroup swung up 2% at the open. Its third-quarter earnings and revenue slipped less than expected.Wells Fargo mustered an 0.8% advance after reporting its third-quarter earnings also slipped less than expected, and revenue rose 2.1%, edging above analyst expectations.Under Armour (UA) clawed up nearly 2% after an upgrade to overweight by Piper Jaffray. Under Armour shares have been struggling against resistance at their 10-week moving average since April.Momo (MOMO), on the IBD 50, climbed 3% at the open. The stock has had a volatile week, after tripping a profit-taking rule following an August breakout.On the downside, India's Infosys (INFY) sliced 5% lower after reporting results in line with lowered guidance, then lowering its full-year revenue guidance due to an "uncertain business outlook."Prices paid to producers rose 0.3% in September, the Labor Department reported, up from a flat performance in August and above forecasts for a 0.2% increase. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2%, up from August's 0.1% gain and above projections for another 0.1% rise.Retail sales surged 0.6%, as expected, in September, reversing the 0.3% dip reported for August by the Commerce Department. Minus autos, sales rose 0.5% -- also in line with projections.At 10 a.m., August business inventories from Commerce and a preliminary consumer sentiment reading for October from the University of Michigan are set for release. Baker Hughes (BHI) serves up its weekly rig count at 1 p.m. ET. The Treasury Budget wraps up Friday's economic calendar at 2 p.m. ET.Oil prices bounced nearly 1% sending West Texas Intermediate to near $51 a barrel. Gold slipped a fraction to below $1,253 an ounce. The dollar gained ground and bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 3 basis points to 1.77%.

It also supplies many of its products to the industrial market that includes customers for kitchen cabinets, office and household furniture, fixtures, and commercial furnishings.Patrick Industries was a finalist for the 2016 Indiana Public Company of the Year, along with fellow RV makers Drew Industries and Thor Industries.After clearing a long consolidation in April, the stock ran up 45% to a 52-week high of 69.53. Since then, it's pulled back and is working on the right side of a second-stage flat base.It dropped below it's 50-day line Friday, but remains in a flat base.Earnings growth has been in the double digits in the past five quarters.A handful of recent leaders among retailers also found institutional support in the past three months. Of those Burlington Stores (BURL), Jack In The Box (JACK) and Wingstop (WING) remained above their 50-day lines, while Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI), Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) fell below.Top-performing funds have been unloading medical giant Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), in their latest reporting periods. The $6.4 billion Fidelity Equity-Income Fund (FEQIX) reduced its shares of the Band-Aid maker.Leading funds also took profit from computer software firm Symantec (SYMC) and workforce-uniform provider Cintas (CTAS).Click Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual FundsRELATED:Top Mutual Fund Stock Buys: Ollie's, Five Below On Shopping Lists

Stocks opened modestly higher Friday as earnings reports and positive economic data from China bolstered investor sentiment.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose less than 0.2%. The Nasdaq was up 0.1%.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each go into Friday's session up 1.6% for the week. The Nasdaq is bucking to end its first week above the 5000 mark since December, and the S&P 500 is lined up for a record high weekly close. The Dow is tracking toward a third straight weekly gain, up nearly 2% for the week through Thursday and also taking out new highs.Small caps have been even more lively, with the Russell 2000 ahead 2.1% through Thursday, though still below its June 2015 peak. The S&P Smallcap 600 heads into today's stock market up 2.4% this week, and just a heartbeat below its June 2015 record.Big banks continued to roll out quarterly results.Citigroup (C) rose 0.2% and Wells Fargo (WFC) slipped 2%, while PNC Financial (PNC)  and U.S. Bancorp (USB) added 0.5% and 1.5%, respectively, after reporting results.India's Infosys (INFY) tumbled 9% after reporting lower-than-expected fiscal first-quarter earnings and revenue., and slashing its full-year sales guidance.Herbalife (HLF) spiked 18% on news that the Federal Trade Commission determined the network marketer was not a pyramid scheme.Rite Aid (RAD) popped 4%, as news reports said the company and Walgreens (WBA) had entered new discussions with the Federal Trade Commission to rescue what is seen as an endangered $17 billion merger. Walgreens shares slipped 0.1%.A wide segment of travel-related stocks were feeling some premarket pressure, possibly from investors reacting to the attack on a Bastille Day crowd in Nice, France. Delta Air Lines (DAL), Expedia (EXPE), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) slipped 1% to 3% at the open.Retail sales rose 0.6% for June, the Commerce Department estimated. That was a nice jump up from May's 0.2% increase, and far above estimates for a 0.1% advance. Minus autos and gas, sales rose 0.7%, vs. 0.3% in May, and better than double consensus views for a 0.3% improvement.June consumer prices were steady. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index ticked up 0.2%, equal to May's gain and a shade below projections for a 0.3% rise. Core prices -- stripping out food and energy -- were the same, up 0.2%, and in line with expectations.New York region manufacturing flattened in July, the New York Federal Reserve reported, with its Empire State Manufacturing Survey showing reading 0.55 for the month. That was sharply below June 6.01 tally, disappointing consensus forecasts for 5.00. New orders and shipment fell to scant gains, and employment and hours worked dipped slightly for the month.June factory capacity and utilization numbers are due out from the Federal Reserve at 9:15 a.m. ET. The University of Michigan delivers its preliminary July consumer sentiment estimate, and the Commerce Department releases May business inventories data, both at 10 a.m. ET.Oil prices could see some effect from Baker Hughes (BHI) weekly rig count, expected at 1 p.m. ET.Oil prices rose nearly 0.6%, putting West Texas Intermediate just below $46 a barrel. Gold slipped a fraction to $1,330 an ounce. The dollar strengthened and the 10-year yield rose 3 basis points to 1.57%.Strong second-quarter GDP growth data out of China helped Asia's markets end a very strong week on a positive note. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.5% Friday to take a 5.3% advance for the week. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 added 0.7% Friday, ending up 9.2% in its best week since December 2009.Europe's markets showed mild losses in afternoon trade. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were tracking toward weekly gains just below 4%. London's FTSE was on to track to end the week up less than 1%.

Big banks JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) got through the second and final round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests unscathed, resulting in a shareholder-returns bonanza shortly after the test results were announced late Wednesday.But Morgan Stanley's (MS) capital plan only got conditional approval, and U.S. segments of Deutsche Bank (DB) and Santander (SAN) failed once againStill, Morgan Stanley said it will move forward with a 33% quarterly dividend hike to 20 cents and a $3.5 billion buyback. JPMorgan OK'd a $10.6 billion buyback but kept its dividend the same. Bank of America announced a $5 billion repurchase program and a 50% payout increase to 7.5 cents. Citigroup will buy back $8.6 billion in stock and raised its payout to 16 cents from 5 cents.Goldman Sachs (GS) didn't give specifics but said its plan included buybacks and a dividend hike. Wells Fargo (WFC)  kept its capital plans unchanged.Morgan Stanley stock were little changed in pre-market trading on the stock market today after rising late Wednesday JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Citigroup climbed 2.4%, Wells Fargo rose and Goldman Sachs all rose fractionally. Deutsche Bank, which the IMF said "poses the greatest risk to the global financial system," sank nearly 4% while Santander fell 2%.Other banks also announced bigger returns to shareholders.The Fed only gave conditional approval to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, in which it projected how it would perform under difficult economic conditions for this year's stress tests. As a result, Morgan must resubmit its capital plan and address broader concerns from the Fed by Dec. 29. If Morgan can't deliver on those promises, the Fed said, its governors "would expect to object" to the resubmitted plan, potentially hindering Morgan's shareholder returns.While the Fed did not technically object to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, the central bank said the company "exhibited material weaknesses in its capital planning process," including in governance, modeling and other safeguards."These weaknesses warrant further near-term attention but do not undermine the quantitative results of the stress tests for the firm," the Fed said, referring to the portion of the tests that quantifies what banks' capital levels would look like under financial turmoil.The Fed said Deutsche Bank and Santander, both of which also had their plans rejected last year, had tightened up some aspects of their capital planning methodology but still struggled with "material unresolved supervisory issues that critically undermine (the) capital planning process."The results follow a pattern of stress-test one-upmanship between the banks, which have been shoring up capital since the financial crisis, and the Fed, which has tried harder each year to catch the banks off-guard in the scenarios posed in the tests.While the banks that passed can move forward with their dividend and buyback hikes, tougher standards on the horizon could keep payouts restrained this year. Fed Governor Daniel Tarullo warned this month that banks in future tests might have to make a "significant increase" in the assets they set aside to cushion against a potential economic crisis.The final round of results from the stress tests -- known as the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, or CCAR -- came after all 33 tested banks last week passed the first round of the evaluation, which quantifies how banks' finances would be affected against a barrage of market shocks.The Fed outlined the economic scenarios for both tests at the beginning of the year. In the weeks that followed, the banks submitted their capital plans, which this year forecast how they would do amid 10% unemployment, negative interest rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries -- among the conditions in the Fed's worst-case scenario.The first round of test results can serve as a preview of sorts to the second, in which the Fed actually indicates whether it accepted, rejected or had any reservations with the banks' capital plans. If it does have an issue, banks could have to temper plans to issue buybacks and boost dividends in order to pass.The second round of tests contains both a quantitative element and qualitative element. The quantitative element measures banks post-stress-test capital levels and whether they could sustain any new dividend and buyback plans. The qualitative element evaluates the soundness of the banks' capital plans and how they were developed.Analysts largely had not anticipated major problems with the banks' stress-test results.

Except for when the Federal Reserve’s more hawkish tone surprised the markets, fixed income funds posted a rather dull performance in May. The yield curve flattened with increased expectations of the Fed hiking interest rates sooner rather than later.Among domestic taxable bond funds, it was loan participation, flexible income and high-yield funds which gained the most, returning 0.81%, 0.75% and 0.53%, respectively, according to preliminary Lipper Inc. data. Treasury inflation protected securities (TIPS) and intermediate U.S. government bond funds underperformed the most, falling a respective 0.69% and 0.16%. They are still up 3.4% and 2.14% for the year.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Six-Month Leaders

“April was eventful from a return standpoint; May was not,” said Timothy Compan Jr., senior portfolio manager fixed income at the PNC Financial Services Group. “If you look at returns for the month, from an excess return standpoint, the numbers are all pretty small.Longer-term general U.S. Treasury funds rose 0.19%, while investment-grade bonds showed mixed but nearly flat performance, with higher-quality ones outperforming the riskier assets.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Category Performance“Credit was a little worse on the month, and most of the structured products, mortgages, asset-backed's, commercial mortgages all had positive excess returns, but we’re talking a few basis points of spread tightening,” said Compan. “High-yield performed well again. That’s the one story that’s interesting. That market continues to do well, especially the riskier credit.”High-yield funds are up 5.8% year to date.Internationally, emerging market local-currency debt funds were the worst performers in May, declining 4.79% as the dollar strengthened. However, they’re still ahead of the pack with a 6.76% jump so far this year. Hard-currency ones fared slightly better, retreating 0.68% in May but still providing investors with a 6.13% return in 2016. Global income funds had a similar performance.In May, “investors (were) reading the tea leaves of the economy to try to ascertain when and at what pace the Fed will raise interest rates,” said Scott Clemons, chief investment strategist for private wealth management at Brown Brothers Harriman. “We got some stronger economic data in the middle of the month that drove rates up.”Clemons believes the economy is in decent shape and does not have any major inflationary pressures. His expectation is one more rate hike this year, probably in the fall and not in June.“That’s what’s going to continue to drive volatility,” he added. “I don’t see any real direction in interest rates unfolding until it’s clear the pace at which the Fed will raise interest rates. That’s the clarity the market doesn’t have.”Fed funds futures prices indicate the chances for an interest rate hike in June fell to 4% Friday after a disappointing jobs report. The figure had climbed to a 30% chance following the release of the latest FOMC minutes.Compan notes that an increase in rates won't have the same impact for investment-grade spreads, though high-yield could be vulnerable.Investment-grade corporates have seen strong demand from the eurozone as investors look for more yield. Compan is constructive on the financial sector due to increased regulation and scrutiny, as well as BBB-rated industrial with the view that the U.S. economy continues to be in a cyclical recovery.That said, PNC has been reducing its exposure to investment-grade corporates when spreads tighten.Further, Compan likes AAA-rated asset-backed securities such as credit cards and auto loans, as they provide more yield but are higher quality. He’s also neutral on mortgages but is starting to like them, while TIPS could be vulnerable to a rate hike.One sector that has shown consistently good returns this year are municipal bonds. General and insured muni debt funds advanced 0.41% last month, amounting to a total gain of 2.68% this year. High-yield muni funds were up 0.79% and 3.88%, respectively. Shorter munis were slightly negative.“The big factor has been limited supply,” Jim Grabovac, managing director and investment strategist at McDonnell Investment Management, told IBD. “Somewhat surprisingly, supply has been on the short side of last year’s pace. Throughout the first five months of the year, we’re down in the vicinity of 8% vs. 2015's pace.”All of the declines have been driven by slower refunding issuance, he said. “One of the factors that could change that dynamic would be the prospect of higher rates.”McDonnell’s Grabovac continues to favor quality, as spreads have been compressing for a while, especially in the high-yield debt. As a result, he prefers adopting a more conservative approach.McDonnell’s managing director Dawn Mangerson says yields are still more attractive in the 10- to 15-year part of the yield curve, and sectors she prefers are utilities, higher education, hospitals and transportation.

Charles Schwab (SCHW) investors are happier than investors with other firms. But investors rank the entire financial industry lower than fields such as technology, food and drink, and pharmaceuticals. Investors’ trust in finance is particularly weak in the U.S., U.K. and Germany, but strong in India and China.Those are the results of new surveys by the CFA Institute and J.D. Power.Schwab tops the list of 21 financial services companies in a poll of investors for the “2016 U.S. Full Service Investor Satisfaction Study.” The report, by marketing and information services firm J.D. Power, said, “Schwab has developed an overall client experience that is closely aligned with the evolving priorities of today’s full-service investor.” The next most popular firms, in order, were Edward Jones, Fidelity Investments and UBS (UBS) Financial Services.At the bottom of the list are LPL Financial (LPLA), PNC (PNC) Wealth Management, Lincoln (LNC) Financial Network and, lowest of all, Voya Financial (VOYA).The financial services industry as a whole ranks below most other industries in “From Trust to Loyalty: A Global Survey of What Investors Want in 2016.” The survey comes from the CFA Institute, which calls itself “a global association of investment professionals.”The technology world ranks at the top; 77% of the survey’s respondents (3,312 retail investors from 10 countries and 502 institutional investors from six countries) say that they trust the tech industry “to do what is right.” In second place (68%) comes the food and beverage industry, followed by brewing and spirits (65%), pharmaceuticals (64%), banks (63%) and telecommunications, energy and consumer packaged goods (62% each).Financial services ranked under all of those industries: 61% of retail investors and 57% of institutional investors said that they trusted the industry.The survey’s other industries were automotive (60%), entertainment (55%) and, coming in dead last, media (47%).The level of trust varied from country to country, the CFA Institute reported. In India, 90% of the survey respondents said that they trust the financial services industry. Just below India was China (89%). From there, the level of trust fell hard: only 64% in Canada and Hong Kong, 63% in Singapore, 55% in France, 54% in the United States, 50% in Australia, 44% in the U.K. and 40% in Germany.

The stock market opened modestly higher Thursday, but early gains faded about 15 minutes after the opening bell.The Nasdaq lost 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 eased less than 0.1%.The market uptrend resumed Wednesday thanks to bullish gains. Both the Nasdaq and S&P 500 open above their 50- and 200-day moving averages and pecking out short-term highs. Small caps had an even better day than the general market on Wednesday, with both the S&P 600 and the Russell 2000 surging 2.2% (vs. 1.5% for the Nasdaq and 1% for the S&P 500).Thursday's economic calendar opened with consumer prices, which the Labor Department reported eked up 0.1% in March. That was an improvement over February's 0.2% decline, but short of expectations for a 0.2% rise. Core prices, minus energy and food, also rose 0.1%. Consensus estimates projected a 0.2% increase.Unemployment claims dropped sharply to 253,000 in the week ended April 9. That was nearly 5% below the prior week's downwardly revised number, and well below expectations for 267,000 claims.Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart said he changed his mind about an April rate hike and will no longer support it. Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell is also scheduled to speak this morning.Crude oil was steady. Gold slipped a fraction. The dollar was steady against the euro but up vs. the yen and most Asian currencies. The 10-year yield rose 2 basis points to 1.79%, as bonds slipped.Nike (NKE) outperformed early in the Dow, rising 1%.Nasdaq 100 firm and S&P 500 component Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was an early riser, up nearly 2%. The casino and resort operator has nearly doubled after hitting a low near 50 in January.Delta Air Lines (DAL) jumped 3.5%. It reported better-than-expected Q1 earnings, but revenue slipped 1.5% to undercut forecasts.Seagate Technology (STX) crumbled 14%, the worst decline among both S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 stocks. The digital hard drive manufacturer warned investors that its fiscal Q3 revenue and margins would undercut prior guidance. The company cited weak demand and inventory reductions.  Peer Western Digital (WDC) also caught the downdraft, slipping 7%.Financial stocks made headlines again. Bank of America (BAC) added 1% after reporting earnings. Wells Fargo (WFC) also reported. Shares fell nearly 1%. PNC Financial (PNC) slipped 1% after a Q1 revenue and earnings miss.

China's latest headline economic figures show that growth is stabilizing and even accelerating, giving a boost to U.S. multinationals and global activity overall. But China's reliance on debt-fueled stimulus may not be sustainable, analysts warn.China grew 6.7% during the first quarter vs. a year earlier, the smallest gain in seven years, Beijing reported Friday local time. But that matched estimates and was only a slight deceleration from Q4's 6.8% expansion.  Also, other economic reports, including retail sales and industrial production, found growth accelerating in March.But even setting aside the usual doubts about whether Chinese economic statistics can be trusted, some analysts worry that China's economy is being propped up by increasing financial leverage and escalating real estate prices."It could take a few years before that is exposed -- as we know from our own economy in the last slowdown," according to Gil Luria, managing director and analyst at Wedbush Securities.The U.S. exposure to China is somewhat limited, comprising barely 1% of U.S. GDP. But stronger Chinese growth could be a boon to U.S. corporate giants, from Apple (AAPL) to United Technologies (UTX) to Starbucks (SBUX).Meanwhile, U.S. and other global stock markets have rallied strongly from early February lows.Crude prices have moved back above $40 a barrel, along with big gains in iron ore and steel prices. That's bolstered commodities-sensitive industries."The indirect price effect is the most important channel through which Chinese growth affects the U.S.," according to William Adams, senior international economist at PNC Financial Services.But questions remain about China, Adams said. In Q1, the three major sectors of the economy -- agriculture, industrial and services -- decelerated from Q4 more than the aggregate growth rate.Retail sales grew 10.5% in March, picking up from 10.2% in February, but China includes government purchases in that number, making it somewhat unclear if actual consumer spending is accelerating.Meanwhile, government measures bolstered China's flagging real estate sector, which had been hampered by a glut of development.Investment in fixed assets such as factories and buildings grew 10.7% in Q1, better than expected. Cement production climbed 24% last month compared to a year earlier. Crude steel production gained 2.9% in March compared to the 5.7% decline during January and February.But private firms' investment rose just 5.7% vs. 23.3% for state-owned businesses. China's state-owned enterprises tend to be less efficient than the country's dynamic private sector.Social financing, which includes bank and nonbank lending, soared to a record high in the first quarter, raising concerns that China has been throwing money at the problem.Still, after a bumpy start to the year, China's policymakers have engineered a soft landing, steadied the yuan and slowed capital outflows."Chinese fiscal stimulus has cushioned the first quarter slowdown and has reduced the downside risks to near-term global growth," Adams said.The world's No. 2 economy is in a well-publicized and long-term transition from an industrial, export-based economy to one led by services and domestic demand. The Chinese consumer's share of GDP rose two points year over year to 56.9%, but that remains far below U.S. numbers.Reform plans to rationalize laggard SOEs have been mooted; Beijing is wary of reforms that would cut millions of jobs. Next year, a lot of provincial officials are up for potential promotions or demotions, according to Sung Wohn Sohn, an economics professor at California State University, Channel Islands. They don't want to risk weak economic figures or widespread labor unrest.Accelerating growth in China and improved global financial markets, even in the short term, should give the Federal Reserve hawks a little more impetus to tighten U.S. monetary policy."They're more likely to raise interest rates now," Sohn said.

The stock market rallied nicely at the open Wednesday as overseas factors, earnings reports and economic data all influenced early trade.The Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 picked up 0.7% each.The stock market today benefited from a positive mood started in Asia. China's March exports surged 12% from a a year ago, the first rise in eight months, according to the General Administration of Customs. Imports declined less than 8%, vs. a 14% drop in February. The export improvement was partially due to a sharp drop in exports in March 2015. Strong exports were also helped by a weaker yuan.Hong Kong's Hang Seng index responded with a 3.2% gain. The Shanghai Composite climbed 1.4%. In Japan, the yen continued lower against the dollar, helping send the Nikkei 225 ahead 2.8%.The positive tone carried over into Europe, where markets pushed strong gains in afternoon trade. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX traded up more than 2% each. London's FTSE 100 showed a 1.4% gain.The overseas momentum helped compensate for the drag caused by oil and gold, both of which traded briskly lower. West Texas Intermediate traded down 1%, but held firmly above $41 a barrel. Gold futures were off nearly 1% to $1,250 an ounce.In U.S. economic news, inflation received a tame report card, as producer prices eased 0.1% in March, the Labor Department estimated, well below the 0.3% increase expected by consensus forecasts. Declines in cost of services apparently offset rebounding energy prices. Core prices, minus energy and food, also dipped 0.1%, vs. forecasts for a 0.2% increase.Retail sales also dropped in March, down 0.3%, Commerce Department data showed. Consensus expectations called for a 0.1% increase. Minus automobiles, sales rose 0.2% -- below the consensus estimate for a 0.4% gain.The Census Bureau offers up February business inventories data at 10 a.m. ET, followed by the Energy Information Administration's weekly oil inventories report at 10:30. The Federal Reserve's beige book report is due out at 2 p.m.JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) paced the Dow in the early going, rising 3% each.JPMorgan outperformed after its Q1 report showed earnings and revenue falling less than anticipated. JPMorgan's Q1 results showed consumer and community banking growing net income 12% on a 4% rise in revenue. Investment banking revenue dropped 24%.Other banks tapped into the momentum. Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and PNC Financial Services (PNC) -- all scheduled to report results on Thursday -- rose 2% apiece. Overseas banks were also in serious motion: Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) leapt 6%, London-based HSBC Holdings (HSBC) swung up 5%. Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), Lloyd's Banking Group (LYG) and UBS Group (UBS) all climbed 3%.Among other companies reporting quarterly results, Adtran (ADTN) jumped 4% after a positive report late Tuesday. Railroad CSX (CSX) rose 1%, as revenue missed and earnings just met analyst consensus estimates, but management reported firmer pricing and rising volumes in automotive and other segments.Beyond earnings, biotech drug maker Medivation (MDVN) sparked up 8% after Bloomberg reported the company had snubbed a buyout offer from French drug giant Sanofi (SNY). Shares of Sanofi added 0.6%.China's Baidu (BIDU) and JD.Com (JD) led the Nasdaq 100, up 3% and 4% respecitively. S&P 500 name Harley Davidson (HOG) rebounded 3.5%. The stock tanked 14% last week on a string of critical analyst notes.Early IBD 50 leaders included Facebook (FB). Shares added more than 1%. The social networking heavy found quiet support at its 50-day line on Tuesday, ending 6% below a 117.09 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Coffee chain Starbucks (SBUX) added 2% after Tuesday's gap down in heavy trade. The stock managed to find support at the converged 50- and 200-day moving averages. That is a positive, but shares have been unable to rise clear of those lines of support as they've climbed the right side of a shallow six-month consolidation.

President Obama is scheduled to visit the United Kingdom this month -- too late to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, but just in time to urge Britons to stay in the European Union, even as it grapples with economic stagnation and a refugee crisis.The possibility that Britain may vote on June 23 to exit the EU has increased anxiety over what could be Europe's biggest political change in decades, raising fears about the EU's survival, global finance and U.S. ties to European allies.Nervousness over a potential "Brexit" is already being felt. The pound has fallen, U.K. construction activity has slowed, and new hiring saw its weakest advance since mid-2013. Consumer confidence in the year ahead, though positive, is at its lowest point since December 2014. And the worst may be yet to come."As we go closer to the actual referendum date, this uncertainty will have a negative impact on U.K. financial markets," said Jacob Funk Kirkegaard, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.It has been enough to worry JPMorgan Chase (JPM) Chairman and CEO Jamie Dimon. In his annual letter to shareholders earlier this week, he warned on a Brexit's negative consequences, including a possible trade war between the U.K. and the remaining EU states that might even threaten the EU's existence."The best case is that Britain can quickly renegotiate hundreds of trade and other contracts with countries around the world, including the European Union," Dimon wrote. “Even this scenario will result in years of uncertainty, and this uncertainty will hurt the economies of both Britain and the European Union."Europe's largest bank, HSBC (HSBC), decided in February to keep its headquarters in London but said it could move 1,000 jobs to Paris if Britain leaves the EU.To Brexit supporters, exiting the EU would save Britain money and restore some of the sovereignty they feel has been lost to Brussels bureaucrats. But others are concerned that a British departure would embolden populist anti-EU political parties such as the National Front in France, Law and Justice in Poland and Podemos in Spain, among others.And after losing a Scottish independence vote in 2014, Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon has said there "almost certainly" would be another independence referendum if the Brexit happens."If the U.K. leaves, what you’ve done for the first time, you’ve now begun to remove one of the main factors that has held Europe together," said Bernard Baumohl, chief global economist at Economic Outlook Group.For the U.S., a Brexit would make global financial regulation more difficult as EU rules mostly likely would differ from their British counterparts. A split in Europe could make steering NATO policy harder. The EU also would become less friendly to the U.S., as Britain often acts as a political bridge between the U.S. and Continental powers such as France and Germany.Analysts are skeptical that the U.K. will vote to leave the EU. Opinion polls currently are close, with the pro-EU camp holding a narrow lead. But British election polls have been wrong before.During last year's general election, pollsters predicted a hung parliament with no majority party. Instead, the Conservative Party won a surprise victory with a slim, though outright, majority in the House of Commons.That political party is now split over Europe. Prime Minister David Cameron is campaigning to remain in the EU, while more than 100 Conservative members of Parliament, including London Mayor Boris Johnson and members of Cameron's cabinet, want to leave.Though the EU is frequently referred to in some quarters as a sluggish mass of red tape, it was once considered a phoenix that rose from the ashes after centuries of war.But its post-World War II successes have been overshadowed by the eurozone's recent economic malaise, the debt crisis and repeated battles over Greece, over Russia's invasion of Ukraine and over millions of refugees from the Mideast and Africa flooding into Europe.The U.K. in general -- and the Conservative Party in particular -- has been reluctant to involve itself too deeply in Continental Europe. In the late 19th century, Britain pursued a policy of "splendid isolation." A Conservative Party split over Europe led directly to Margaret Thatcher's downfall as prime minister in 1990. When the euro was adopted as a currency, Britain kept the pound.As Europe's problems mounted after the financial crisis of 2008, the voices of those skeptical of the EU became louder across the union. In Britain, the populist United Kingdom Independence Party (UKIP) challenged the Conservatives on their right flank.UKIP won 12.6% of the vote in last year's election, though it only won one seat in Parliament due to the U.K.'s first-past-the-post electoral system. But in response to the emerging electoral threat, Cameron promised a referendum on Britain's EU membership."Dissatisfaction with the EU is pretty widespread across the entire union," said William Adams, senior international economist at PNC Financial Services Group. "This is not going to be the end of political uncertainty around this EU project."

The U.S. economy grew in the fourth quarter at a faster pace than previously estimated, supported by stronger household spending that’s helping cushion the expansion from weakness overseas.The revised 1.4% increase in gross domestic product, the value of all goods and services produced, compares with the Commerce Department’s previous estimate of 1%, according to figures issued Friday. The economy grew 2% in the third quarter. The report also showed that corporate profits dropped in 2015 by the most in seven years.The earnings slump illustrates the limits of an economy struggling to gather steam at the start of this year. Some companies, encumbered by low commodities prices and sluggish foreign markets, are cutting back on investment while a firm labor market and low inflation encourage households to keep shopping.“It’s really U.S. consumers who are powering the global economy forward at this point,” said Gus Faucher, an economist at PNC Financial Services in Pittsburgh. At the same time, “there are pressures on businesses in terms of the stronger dollar, rising labor costs and slowing productivity growth” even as a rise in energy prices will help ease that drag for oil producers.The median forecast of 73 economists surveyed by Bloomberg called for fourth-quarter growth of 1%, with projections ranging from no change to a 1.4% gain. This is the last of three estimates for the quarter before annual revisions in July.The figure marks a slowdown from the 2.2% average pace in the first three quarters of 2015. For all of last year, the U.S. economy grew 2.4%, matching the advance in 2014.Today’s fourth-quarter growth figure reflected more spending on services, particularly on recreation and transportation. Exports also declined less than previously estimated.Household purchases, which account for almost 70% of the economy, rose at a 2.4% annual pace, compared with a previously estimated 2% rate. Personal consumption added 1.66 percentage points to growth.Weak overseas demand has weighed on net exports, with trade subtracting 0.14 percentage point from overall growth after a previously reported 0.25 percentage point. The gap in goods and services trade may stay wide as the U.S. economy plods ahead and foreign markets, including China, struggle to improve.Inventories subtracted 0.22 percentage point from growth compared with a previous estimate of a 0.14 percentage-point drag. American companies are still trying to get stockpiles more in line with demand.Final Sales

Stripping out inventories and trade, the two most volatile components of GDP, so-called final sales to domestic purchasers increased at a 1.7% rate, compared with a previously estimated 1.4% pace.Friday’s report also offered a first look at corporate profits for the period. Pre-tax earnings declined 7.8%, the most since the first quarter of 2011, after a 1.6% decrease in the previous three months. The estimate of nonfinancial corporate profits was reduced by a $20.8 billion settlement, considered a transfer to the government, between BP (BP) and the U.S. after the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.Profits in the U.S. dropped 3.1% in 2015, the most since 2008. Earnings are being weighed down by weak productivity, rising labor costs and the plunge in energy prices.“If profits remain depressed, the prospects for capex and hiring will come under greater pressure,” Sam Bullard, a senior economist at Wells Fargo Securities in Charlotte, North Carolina, wrote in a research note.Corporate outlays for equipment declined at a 2.1% annualized pace, subtracting 0.12 percentage point, the Commerce Department said.A strengthening labor market is supporting steady U.S. household demand even as factories continue to struggle amid the global slowdown. Employers added 242,000 workers to payrolls in February and the unemployment rate held at an eight-year low of 4.9 percent. Firings linger near four-decade lows.Consumers have also been buoyed by gasoline prices. The cost of an average gallon of regular gasoline was $2.01 as of March 23, compared with $2.40 on average for all of 2015, according to motoring group AAA.

Stocks got off to a positive start, then fell into mild losses early Friday, despite a surprise jump in January consumer sentiment.The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.4%. The S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Nasdaq eased 0.1%.Volume rose 13% on the Nasdaq and 54% on the NYSE compared with trade at the same time Thursday.The stock market today appeared to shed its weak premarket posture, opening higher on strong trade. The Dow was the first to drop into negative territory, weighed by Intel (INTC), Caterpillar (CAT) and Wal-Mart (WMT).Early consumer price data were, if not positive, at least in line with expectations, showing the bulk of the month's decline's owing to gasoline prices.The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production eased 0.1% in December, down from November's 1.3% jump but in line with economists' projections. Utilization of factory capacity was 79.7%, just below expectations.The University of Michigan delivered good news, with its initial estimate on January consumer sentiment jumping to 98.2. That was up from 93.6 in December and well above forecasts for a reading of 94.In stocks, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) spiked 6% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) topped the Dow, up more than 1% each, although oil prices pulled back from an early, 3% gain.A raft of earnings reports from big banks stirred a share of Friday's early action. SunTrust Banks (STI) surged 5% to top the S&P 500. PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) popped 2% higher. Brokerage Charles Schwab (SCHW) gained a fraction, while Goldman Sachs (GS) dipped 0.4%.Oilfield service shaker Schlumberger (SLB) rode up nearly 4%. It reported late Thursday that its Q4 earnings topped expectations. Revenue growth stopped short of views, but the company announced it would cut its 2015 capital expenditures by 25% and lay off 9,000 workers. The stock was 50% below its early July high.Leading stocks posted a healthy start, with some 80% of the IBD 50 list stocks moving higher at the open.Ambarella (AMBA) led the group with a 3% advance. The maker of chips used in GoPro (GPRO) and other digital video cameras is rebounding after three straight losses left the stock down 13% at the end of Thursday's session and just short of a test of its 10-week moving average. GoPro shares were down nearly 3% Friday, trading 52% below an early October high.Losses on the IBD 50 list were mild, with the deepest cut being a 1% drop by Align Technology (ALGN).

China's government announced new financial regulations, sending Chinese stocks sharply lower Tuesday and briefly hitting U.S. markets, even as some analysts said the measures should help the country's long-term prospects. Bonds rated below AAA or sold by issuers graded lower than AA may no longer be used as collateral in certain short-term loans, the government said. That caused a sell-off…

The Small Business Administration is under fire for lending billions of taxpayer dollars a year to exclusive country clubs, golf resorts, yacht clubs, pet resorts, upscale plastic surgeons, wineries and other businesses catering to the lifestyles of the very wealthy. A new report by the federal spending watchdog OpentheBooks.com has uncovered these and other questionable loan activities by the SBA…

Brent and West Texas intermediate declined for the first time in three days as investors weighed the odds of a production cut from OPEC this week. Hedge funds have turned less bullish on oil in the absence of any clear signal from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that it will act to bolster prices. Rumblings about monetary easing from China and Europe are expected to have, at best, a modest economic impact both there and in the U.S., which has been strengthening while other top economies are weakening. In a surprise move, China's central bank cut lending rates Friday for the first time in two years, slicing its one-year benchmark rate by 40 basis…

Regional banking powers U.S. Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial Services (PNC) both beat quarterly earnings views Wednesday, though both stocks were lower in midday trading on the stock market. Reporting before the open, Minneapolis-based U.S. Bancorp delivered second-quarter earnings of 78 cents a share, up from 76 cents the previous year and a penny above consensus estimates. Revenue gained 5%…
U.S. manufacturing growth eased in September, a pair of industry reports showed Wednesday, but activity remains brisk amid global economic and geopolitical woes.

ISM's overall manufacturing index was 56.6, down 2.4 points from August's 3 1/2-year high. The new orders gauge eased back to a strong 60, and employment dipped 3.5 points to 54.6. Production edged up to its best reading in more than four years.

The numbers confirm a purchasing managers index from Markit, which shed 0.4 point to 57.5 in September, as well as multiple surveys from regional Federal Reserve banks, many of which have beat expectations in recent weeks.

"Even though we saw a drop, the levels are still firm and the story line from the sentiment surveys remains the same," said Mike Englund, chief economist of Action Economics. "We basically still have an updraft in the numbers."

ISM's headline number averaged 57.6 in Q3, a figure that's gained each quarter in 2014. Englund thinks that's a sustainable pace for manufacturing, though he expects it to fall back toward 54 in 2015.
SUV Sales Hot

U.S. factories have enjoyed many advantages in 2014. Consumers have rushed to replace older automobiles as dealers offer incentives. Q3 auto sales ran at the best rate in eight years, though there are signs that may be slowing down. General Motors (GM) on Wednesday reported strong September U.S. sales of SUVs and large pickups, helped by falling gasoline prices. But Ford (F) said its overall domestic sales declined slightly.

There are also signs that a long-awaited rebound in business capital spending is finally at hand. Capacity utilization, a measure of how much slack firms have in their equipment, stands just below 80%, the point at which firms can no longer put off new investment. And core capital goods orders, a proxy for business investment, are up 7.8% for the year.
"I do think businesses are finally feeling comfortable enough to go out and invest and that'll be a positive for the next year," said Gus Faucher, senior economist with PNC Financial Services.
ISM survey respondents also were bullish, citing better orders from the end of the government's fiscal year, consumers with more disposable income, and a stronger multi-family housing sector.

"We are seeing shipments up, year-over-year, in the 8% to 10% range for the last couple of months. This is good," said one. Another noted stronger demand for "defense requirements," thanks to global political unrest.
But there are still many potential headwinds for U.S. factories.
Markit's eurozone PMI for September was just above the neutral 50, while Germany, which has led growth, unexpectedly dipped below that line, to 49.9.
China's economy may be slowing faster than the government wants, and Japan's hasn't bounced back as quickly from April's big sales tax hike.
Those macro concerns, along with continued unrest in Hong Kong and Ukraine, sent U.S. stocks sharply lower on Wednesday. The Nasdaq sank 1.6% and the S&P 500 1.3%.
A more sluggish world growth scenario "is a concern to the extent that the U.S. can't carry the load by itself the whole way," Faucher said.

The U.S. does benefit from being the best house in a bad neighborhood, Englund said. "World willingness to take risk is diminished but to the extent people are willing, the U.S. is the best bet," he said.U.S. manufacturing growth eased in September, a pair of industry reports showed Wednesday, but activity remains brisk amid global economic and geopolitical woes.ISM's overall manufacturing index was 56.6, down 2.4 points from August's 3 1/2-year high. The new orders gauge eased back to a strong 60, and employment dipped 3.5 points to 54.6. Production edged up to its best reading in more than four years.The numbers confirm a purchasing managers index from Markit, which shed 0.4 point to 57.5 in September, as well as multiple surveys from regional Federal Reserve banks, many of which have beat expectations in recent weeks."Even though we saw a drop, the levels are still firm and the story line from the sentiment surveys remains the same," said Mike Englund, chief economist of Action Economics. "We basically still have an updraft in the numbers."ISM's headline number averaged 57.6 in Q3, a figure that's gained each quarter in 2014. Englund thinks that's a sustainable pace for manufacturing, though he expects it to fall back toward 54 in 2015.SUV Sales HotU.S. factories have enjoyed many advantages in 2014. Consumers have rushed to replace older automobiles as dealers offer incentives. Q3 auto sales ran at the best rate in eight years, though there are signs that may be slowing down. General Motors (GM) on Wednesday reported strong September U.S. sales of SUVs and large pickups, helped by falling gasoline prices. But Ford (F) said its overall domestic sales declined slightly.There are also signs that a long-awaited rebound in business capital spending is finally at hand. Capacity utilization, a measure of how much slack firms have in their equipment, stands just below 80%, the point at which firms can no longer put off new investment. And core capital goods orders, a proxy for business investment, are up 7.8% for the year."I do think businesses are finally feeling comfortable enough to go out and invest and that'll be a positive for the next year," said Gus Faucher, senior economist with PNC Financial Services.ISM survey respondents also were bullish, citing better orders from the end of the government's fiscal year, consumers with more disposable income, and a stronger multi-family housing sector."We are seeing shipments up, year-over-year, in the 8% to 10% range for the last couple of months. This is good," said one. Another noted stronger demand for "defense requirements," thanks to global political unrest.But there are still many potential headwinds for U.S. factories.Markit's eurozone PMI for September was just above the neutral 50, while Germany, which has led growth, unexpectedly dipped below that line, to 49.9.China's economy may be slowing faster than the government wants, and Japan's hasn't bounced back as quickly from April's big sales tax hike.Those macro concerns, along with continued unrest in Hong Kong and Ukraine, sent U.S. stocks sharply lower on Wednesday. The Nasdaq sank 1.6% and the S&P 500 1.3%.A more sluggish world growth scenario "is a concern to the extent that the U.S. can't carry the load by itself the whole way," Faucher said.The U.S. does benefit from being the best house in a bad neighborhood, Englund said. "World willingness to take risk is diminished but to the extent people are willing, the U.S. is the best bet," he said.

So on Friday – stocks ended slightly lower...consolidating really after the rally that has seen the Dow , S&P and Nasdaq all move higher by about 6% in the last week halting just at initial resistance levels. Have investors decided that all of the chatter about a weakening economy is just that? Chatter? Have they decided that the selloff in January and February was a bit overdone? Well before we tackle those questions – remember that bear mkt rallies can be dramatic events and we have yet to break out of the bear trend – so now is the time for some analysis.Remember on Sesame Street – when Bert and Ernie wanted to introduce a new letter? They would say something like: "Today we are gonna learn about the letter (insert letter here). Well - folks - today we are going to learn about a letter that plays an important role for technicians and one that can be seen clearly when you look at the charts....It is the letter "W".Notice that the letter "W" has a descending left arm , a bottom, then a spike up, only to make another bottom before bouncing and creating the ascending right arm.... and this is called a "double bottom". You see that right - The Double Bottom?For well over 2 ½ months now the mkt has been struggling – the bulls and the bears have been at each other"s throat"s – and while this has been going on – something else has been happening. A quick look at the Dow, the S&P, will reveal a "W" trading pattern. The descending left side beginning in early January took us to the first bottom on Jan 20th….then the mkt began to rise – making its top on Feb 1st – only to turn south again and make the second bottom on Feb 11th – at about the time that Janet Yellen was testifying in front of congress – suggesting that 4 rate hikes were most likely "not going to happen in 2016" and this is when the ascending right side began to form.Now the logical follow thru of this pattern is for the mkt to create the right hand side of the W that we can expect to test (at least) its 50 dma (1955) where it should find plenty of resistance, but In fact – if it were true to the pattern then it should really pierce the 50 dma and attempt to test its 200 dma at 2030 (now in this environment - I think that is a bit of stretch) - it is a tall order, but one that is not out of the question at all in terms of technical patterns.So what would help propel us to that level? Well, a bunch of things really, but clearly one of them is oil! Last week, on the 16th, we saw oil pierce the $30 level and trade as high as $31.53......and coincidentally - this was the same day that the mkt rocketed higher, as the word then was that oil had put in a bottom, so the trader types hit the BUY button as " FOMO" (Fear of Missing Out) took hold of their senses.... ......and when oil failed to rally further - the mkt stalled a bit - digesting the move higher and waiting for direction.Well - it is getting that direction today....Oil has once again begun to move and the move is higher... WTI is trading up $1 or 3.3% and so US futures are up 22 pts in early pre-mkt trading...Now if it holds here into the opening - then the S&P would immediately trade to 1935.....determined to at least test and pierce its Feb 1st high of 1943 before it can make a run at its 50 dma at 1955. And if that is true - then the "W" pattern will be on its way to completion. Once we get there though, I would expect there to be some resistance....On Friday we learned that consumer prices - as measured by the CPI (Consumer Price Index) are in fact accelerating - despite the collapse in so many commodities....The gov't told us that year over year - CORE CPI - that is ex food and energy - was up 2.2% .....Gus Faucher - PNC Economist was quick to point out that this"Broad based price growth is signalling that the wage and price pressures are building, an indication that the economy is expanding at a solid pace and that recessionary concerns are overdone"To that I say - Come on Gussy.....really? The FED uses the "Personal Consumption Expenditures Index" to measure inflation and that my friend only shows a 0.6% increase year over year (well below the 2% target).......and besides we have a dozen other macro data points, strong dollar and a weak employment picture that all signal a slowdown and now you are telling us that this one report - that is EX food and energy - changes the whole picture? If that is the case- then you are calling for the FED to move on rates - and if that is true - then the mkt would be backing off considering the broader global economy continues to struggle. And it isn't!Now this morning global mkts are screaming higher...... - we can thank this move on higher oil - The head of OPEC & the Saudi oil minister are set to speak today at an energy conference in Houston - so we can credit the move to this anticipated discussion....- Recall that last week - 4 major producers did say that they would freeze production at January levels and that is what started the rally in oil....so any new news today will be seen as a positive - because the sense is that they are NOT going to announce a cancellation of that prior announcement.In addition the news in Europe was not bullish at all....European Flash PMI's for February were disappointing.... German Manufacturing PMI was 50.2 vs.52.0 expectation and the European Monetary Union (EMU) Manufacturing PMI was 51.0 vs. 52.0 expectation. But those mkts are solidly higher because of the possibility of further ECB easing. (there is that whole NEGATIVE rate discussion rearing its ugly head) FTSE+1.26%, CAC 40 +1.77%, DAX +1.95%, EUROSTOXX +2.07%, SPAIN +2.18% and ITALY +2.88%.As noted S&P futures are +22 pts.... with little eco data today - I suspect that traders will be listening intently to the comments coming from the energy conference in Houston.Today we will get Markit US Manf PMI - exp of 52.5.......and considering manufacturing has been a sore spot for this recovery - this will be an interesting stat to watch.....an upside surprise (which would be interesting) is unlikely but if so - then watch for the mkt to back off a bit as the speculation will return to FED policy
Take Good Care

Exposure to energy in Wells Fargo (WFC) and an underwhelming global banking performance for Citigroup (C) factored in as they, along with U.S. Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings Friday.

Wells Fargo said it earned $1.03 a share for the quarter, up 1% from a year earlier and beating by a penny the estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 0.7% to $21.6 billion, missing estimates of $21.8 billion. Full-year EPS was $4.15 a share, up 1.2% from 2014's total and matched views. Full-year revenue rose 2% to $86.1 billion, missing views of $86.5 billion.

As of Dec. 31, total assets rose 6% to $1.8 trillion compared with a year earlier. Total loans rose 6.3% to $916.6 billion. Total consumer loans grew 2.7% to $460 billion. Commercial loans grew 10% to $456.6 billion.

Wells' net interest margin, the difference between what banks earn in loans vs. what they pay out to depositors, slipped to 2.92% from the third quarter's 2.96% and 3.04% a year earlier. The Federal Reserve's decision to boost interest rates by 0.25% last month — the first interest rate hike since 2006 — is seen as helping boost banks' profitability. But the brutal start to the year for stocks, weak global growth and underwhelming inflation numbers could mean that further hikes could be delayed.

The sagging energy sector also weighed on Wells Fargo to some degree. The San Francisco-based bank reported $831 million in credit losses in the fourth quarter, up 18.2% from the quarter before, primarily due to $90 million in higher oil and gas portfolio losses as well as seasonal increases in non-real estate consumer portfolios. Costs decreased 2% to $12.4 billion from $12.65 billion, reflecting savings on employee benefits and commissions.

Shares tumbled 4.2% to 48.51 on the stock market today. Wells Fargo's IBD Composite Rating is 64 out of 99, meaning it is outperforming 64% of other publicly traded companies. It is trading well below its 50-day moving average, and that fell below its 200-day line back in September.

Meanwhile, Citigroup reported quarterly earnings of $1.06 a share, also beating views by a penny. The New York-based bank earned 6 cents a share in the year-ago quarter because of legal expenses. Revenue rose 4% to $18.6 billion, beating estimates of $17.9 billion. Full-year EPS was $5.35 a share, missing views by 9 cents, but during the year the bank earned $17.2 billion, its biggest profit in nearly a decade. For all of 2014, Citigroup earned $2.20 a share. Full-year revenue fell 1.5% to $76.1 billion, but beat estimates of $75.6 billion.

Allowance for loan losses was $12.6 billion at the end of the quarter, or 2.1% of total loans. A year earlier, that total was $16 billion, or $2.5% of total loans. Citi set aside $250 million to cover losses to its energy portfolio.

Operating expenses fell 23% to $11.1 billion, driven by lower legal costs. Loans fell 4% to $618 billion while deposits rose 1% to $908 billion. Net interest margins slipped to 2.92% compared with 2.94% in the third quarter.

Profit at Citi Holdings, Citigroup's "bad bank" that has housed the company's sour assets since the 2008-09 financial crisis, soared to $704 million from $87 million a year earlier, thanks in part to the sale of OneMain Financial Group, Citi's subprime lending unit. Net income at Citi's global banking unit fell 20% to $1.3 billion and income from its institutional clients group dropped 18% to $1.4 billion.

Citi has sought to become leaner and meaner since the financial crisis. It has sold off a number of its overseas assets in order to slim down. Total assets as of Dec. 31 were $1.7 trillion, putting it behind Wells Fargo in that department.
Citi's shares sank 6.5% to 42.43, well below its 50-day line, which fell below its 200-day moving average in October. Its IBD Composite Rating is 48.

Elsewhere, U.S. Bancorp earned 80 cents a share for the quarter, up 1.3% and beating views by a penny. Revenue fell 0.2% to $5.2 billion, beating estimates of $5.1 billion. Full-year EPS was $3.16, up 2.6% from the previous year, matching views. Full-year revenue rose 2.5% to $20.1 billion, missing views of $20.2 billion.
The Minneapolis-based bank earned $294 million in fees from credit and debit cards, up 8.1% and helping to offset declines in mortgage banking and investment product revenue.

Net interest margin rose to 3.06% compared with the third quarter's 3.04%, but fell from Q4 2014's 3.14%. Average total loans grew 4.2% from a year earlier to $256.7 billion while total deposits grew 6.9% to $294.5 billion. As of Dec. 31, 2015, total assets were $421.9 billion, up 4.8%.
U.S. Bancorp.'s provision for credit losses rose 5.9% to $305 million. The allowance for credit losses was $4.3 billion, down 1.6% from a year earlier.
Shares fell 3% to 38.72, well below its 50-day average. U.S. Bancorp's IBD Composite Rating is 64.

Finally, PNC Financial Services Group earned $1.87 a share, up 1.6% year over year and beating quarterly views by 7 cents. Revenue fell 2.4% to $3.9 billion, beating estimates of $3.8 billion. Full-year EPS was $7.39 a share, up 1.2% from 2014, and beat views by 9 cents. Full-year revenue was $15.2 billion, a 1% decline, but ahead of estimates of $15.1 billion.

The Pittsburgh-based bank's net interest margin was 2.7%, down from 2.89% a year earlier, but an improvement over the third quarter's 2.67%. Total assets were $358.5 billion as of Dec. 31, up 3.9% from a year earlier. Total loans grew 1% to $206.7 billion. Total deposits grew 7% to $249 billion.
Provisions for credit losses were $74 million compared to the third quarter's $81 million while PNC's allowance for loan and lease losses fell 18% to $2.7 billion.
Shares fell 1.4% to 85.66, below both their 50- and 200-day moving averages. The company's IBD Composite Rating is 57.

Big banks' earnings season resumes Tuesday when Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) report their Q4 and full-year results. Goldman Sachs (GS) reports on Wednesday. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) issued its quarterly and annual earnings report on Thursday.

Investors have bid up bank stocks in recent months on any shred of evidence that the Fed would soon raise interest rates, only to have their hopes dashed.

So when the Fed actually does raise rates — as it's expected to do next month in light of last Friday's surprisingly stellar jobs report — will bank investors finally reap the rewards? It depends on whom you ask.

Banking experts agree that a short-term rate increase is good for banks since it boosts their net interest margins. Revenue from lending money goes up faster than the cost of interest they pay on deposits, boosting earnings.

"That increased spread would definitely benefit the banks, which is why we've seen bank stocks outperform when there's increased talk of a fed rate hike," said strategist Ed Yardeni. "It's good for bank earnings and it's good for bank stocks."
Chris Mutascio, a bank analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, counters that one modest rate hike from the Fed and not another for some time "is not going to help earnings much."
"We just lowered estimates on seven or eight banks" for 2016 and 2017, he said, including Bank of America (BAC), PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM).
Bank of America has said that every 100 basis-point hike in the rate would boost revenue by $4.5 billion.

But since Oct. 1, analysts' estimates for the first quarter of 2016 have come down, according to Thomson Reuters. For large diversified banks, earnings estimates went from 8.3% to 5% on Friday. For overall financials, estimates fell from 5.6% to 2.6%.

"There is still earnings pressure on the banks," said Mutascio, adding that the U.S. economy is chugging along at 2% or so growth while the global economy is weakening. Some analysts say the prospect of higher interest rates may already be baked into earnings estimates.
"If the Fed does not raise rates substantially, you could see earnings misses from the banks next year," Mutascio said. Most experts expect the Fed will move slow in raising rates.
Analysts see JPMorgan's earnings growing only 4% next year, following an expected 13% gain this year. But Bank of America's are expected to jump 300% this year and 9% next year.

Estimates tend to fall as a quarter nears, "but it's still early for the first quarter to come down much," said Greg Harrison, analyst at Thomson Reuters. "The first quarter is another three months off and banks won't start reporting until April."

Revenue estimates, which tend to be more stable, also have fallen since Oct. 1. For general financial companies, they went from 2.1% to 1.7%. Still, a rate hike could be enough to push bank stocks higher on "market sentiment" alone, especially banks that are "asset sensitive," says Jeff Harte, analyst with Sandler O'Neill.

"The trust banks such as Bank of New York (BK) and Northern Trust (NTRS) are very asset sensitive. They'll benefit," Harte said. "Some of the money-center banks such as Bank of America, JPMorgan and Citigroup (C) will benefit too."

"Rising rates will be good news for bank stocks," he said. "But not hiking rates in the next six months would be bad news. Investors are already pricing in higher rates."Investors have bid up bank stocks in recent months on any shred of evidence that the Fed would soon raise interest rates, only to have their hopes dashed.So when the Fed actually does raise rates — as it's expected to do next month in light of last Friday's surprisingly stellar jobs report — will bank investors finally reap the rewards?
